column5: I had a response to a thread I did a while back when I made my clousers . Buddy said I should tie some on a siwash hooks for behind dodgers for salmon trolling. So i did and wait to hear back how they work. The green and black one has a trailer hook. It stuck me like 6 X tying the front hook.ðŸ˜‚ Hooks I used are super sharp and strong         The trailer one. I call it,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,  I BITE BACK
Dude they are great where do I place my order lol
Even tying those behind a Williams would be killer.Â  Â Early season laker killer!

I'd tie them with a second hook facing up as a stinger , dodger fly was the hot setup 40+ years ago when Lake Ontario was Coho fishery. Blue zone ( but that name evolved later ) 20 feet down,Â  Red Luhr Jensen dodger blue Jonsfly , six feet behind the ball ,Â  Cohoes all summer until they stacked up at the mouths.
Thats what I did. That,s why I got stuck so many times. LOL
That is what I was thinking when I made the 1st 3 . I even told him they were coho baits. Thanks Dave

Elaborate Bill please,,,,,,,,  You mean tie a treble up for the spoon, or for a trailer behind it ? The spoon would act as a mini dodger ? I can visually see that working .  EDIT Making a trailer in a shiner/herring pattern would work I am sure . Food for thought. Will have to keep my eye open for those old William spoons. The large ones.
Even used a wooly worm fly a foot or so behind a hookless Williams for trolling spring Specs.
Yup, I've used it a few time.  Brian, yeah.Â  The Williams basically becomes the dodger in this case.Â  Â Remove the hook , run a lead and tie on that fly.
Thanks Bill for the reply  Guess I got to make a few for Terry now. LOL  PayPal or direct cash in hand WITH COVID proof gloves, woks for me. LMAO ðŸ¤£
Tomorrows project buddy,  What else am I going to do at 4 am ??????????
They are the cats behind Brian. If I get back the fishing bug I will look you up!ðŸ™‚
